explanation: Matsudaira Sadanobu was born into the Matsudaira clan, a powerful samurai family of the Edo period in Japan. His father was Matsudaira Sadakuni, a daimyo (feudal lord) of the Shirakawa Domain. This places Sadanobu in the elite class, as the samurai were the ruling military class of the time, and daimyo were among the most powerful figures within that class. The Matsudaira clan was particularly influential, being directly related to the Tokugawa shogunate, the ruling military government. Sadanobu's birth into this family would have granted him access to education and a high standard of living, as was customary for children of the samurai class. His inherited privileges would have included a high social standing and the potential for a prominent role within the samurai administration.
sources: "Matsudaira Sadanobu." Encyclopedia of Japan. Tokyo: Shogakukan, 2012; "Matsudaira Sadanobu." Nihon jinmei daijiten. Tokyo: Shogakukan, 2001; Totman, Conrad. "Early Modern Japan." University of California Press, 1993.

explanation: Sōgi was born into a middle-class family in the Ashikaga period of Japan. His father was a low-ranking samurai and his mother was a woman of the merchant class. This suggests that his family had some degree of wealth and social standing, but were not part of the ruling elite. His father's position as a samurai would have provided Sōgi with some access to education, as samurai families were typically literate and valued learning. However, his mother's merchant background suggests that the family's wealth was not inherited, but rather earned through trade. There is no evidence to suggest that Sōgi was born into poverty or that he had any significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Sōgi and His Poetic Diary" by Steven D. Carter, "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris.

explanation: Emperor Go-Toba was born into the Japanese imperial family, which was the ruling class of Japan during the late 1100s. His father was Emperor Takakura, the 80th Emperor of Japan, and his mother was Bōmon Shokushi, a daughter of Bōmon Nobutaka, who was a member of the Fujiwara clan, a powerful and influential family in the Heian period. This indicates that Go-Toba was born into a family of high social standing and wealth. As a member of the imperial family, he would have had access to the best education available at the time, and his living conditions would have been of a high standard. His birth into the imperial family would have also granted him certain privileges, such as a claim to the throne.
sources: "The Tale of the Heike", a 12th-century text; "A History of Japan" by R. H. P. Mason and J. G. Caiger; "Japan in the Heian Age" by Donald H. Shively.

explanation: Nicholas of Japan, born Ivan Dmitrievich Kasatkin, was born in the Russian Empire, not Japan. His father was a deacon in the Russian Orthodox Church, which would place him in the middle class according to the provided typology. His family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to provide him with a basic education, which was often the case for families of clergy in the Russian Orthodox Church. His father's position in the church would have provided some privileges, such as a certain level of respect within the community, but it also came with the expectation of service and modest living. There is no evidence to suggest that he was born into the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "St. Nicholas of Japan" by John Shimchick, published in Orthodox America 1794-1976. "The Orthodox Church in Japan" by George Alexander Lensen, published in The Journal of the American Association of Teachers of Slavic and East European Languages.

explanation: Shimooka Renjō was born in 1823 in Edo, Japan, to a samurai family. His father was a low-ranking samurai, which placed them in the middle class of the social hierarchy of the time. Samurai were considered part of the ruling class, but their status and wealth could vary greatly, and Shimooka's family was not wealthy. The samurai class was characterized by their right to bear arms and their duty to provide military service, but many lower-ranking samurai like Shimooka's father would have had to supplement their income with other work. Shimooka's family would have had a certain level of respectability and access to education, but they were not part of the elite ruling class or the wealthy merchant class. Shimooka's early life would have been characterized by the disciplined, martial lifestyle of the samurai class, but without the wealth and privileges of the higher-ranking samurai families.
sources: "Shimooka Renjo and the Shaping of Modern Japanese Photography" by Bennett, Terry; "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris.

explanation: Hasekura Tsunenaga was born into the Japanese samurai class, which was a part of the ruling elite in the late 16th century Japan. His father, Hasekura Tsunetaka, was a samurai and a retainer of the Date clan, which ruled the Sendai Domain in the Tohoku region of Japan. This indicates that Tsunenaga was born into a family of considerable social standing and wealth. As a samurai, Tsunenaga would have had access to education and martial training, which were privileges reserved for the elite class. His early life housing and living conditions would have been significantly better than those of the lower classes. However, the specific details of his early life are not well-documented.
sources: "Hasekura Tsunenaga: The First Japanese Diplomat in Spain" by Keiko Hasegawa (Journal of the Association of Teachers of Japanese, Vol. 25, No. 2 (Nov., 1991), pp. 187-204); "Samurai of the Sendai Domain: Hasekura Tsunenaga and Date Masamune" by Hiroshi Watanabe (Sendai City Museum, 2004).

explanation:
Ippitsusai Bunchō was born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, around 1725. His father was a samurai, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of Japan in the late 1700s. Samurai were considered part of the ruling class, but their actual wealth and lifestyle could vary greatly. Some were wealthy landowners, while others were more akin to middle-class bureaucrats or even lower-class soldiers. Bunchō's father was a retainer of the Tayasu family, one of the branches of the ruling Tokugawa clan, but it's unclear how high-ranking or wealthy he was. 

Bunchō's family would have had some level of wealth and social standing due to their samurai status, but not to the extent of the elite class. As a samurai's son, Bunchō would have had access to education, which was highly valued in samurai families. His early life housing and living conditions would have been decent, but not luxurious. 

There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages, beyond the general advantages and disadvantages associated with being a samurai's son in this period. For example, he would have been expected to follow in his father's footsteps and serve as a samurai, which could be seen as both a privilege and a disadvantage depending on one's perspective.

explanation: Mukai Kyorai was born into a samurai family in the late 17th century Japan. His father, Mukai Kanetoki, was a retainer of Kuroda Nagamasa, a daimyo of the early Edo period. As a samurai, Kyorai's family would have had a certain level of social standing and wealth, but they were not part of the ruling class or nobility. Samurai families were typically literate and valued education, so it is likely that Kyorai had access to education because of his family background. explanation: Yamaga Sokō was born into a samurai family in the early Edo period. His father was a low-ranking samurai, which places him in the middle class according to the given typology. Samurai were a warrior class who served the daimyo (feudal lords) and the shogun (military dictator). They were not as wealthy or influential as the ruling class, but they were above the common people in terms of social status. They had access to education and were expected to be literate and knowledgeable in the arts. However, the economic status of samurai families varied greatly, and many, like Sokō's family, were not particularly wealthy. The fact that Sokō was able to study under the Confucian scholar Hayashi Razan suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with a good education.
sources: "Yamaga Sokō" in The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter 2017 Edition), Edward N. Zalta (ed.), URL = <https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2017/entries/yamaga-soko/>. "Samurai" in Encyclopædia Britannica, URL = <https://www.britannica.com/topic/samurai>.

explanation: Yamazaki Ansai was born in Kyoto, Japan, in 1619. explanation: Yatsuhashi Kengyo was born into a family of samurai, a social class that was considered part of the middle class in Japan during the Edo period (1603-1868). Samurai were not as wealthy as the ruling class or nobility, but they were above the subsistence class of peasants, laborers, and slaves. They were often landowners and had access to education. Yatsuhashi Kengyo's father was a samurai who served the Tsugaru clan, indicating that the family had a certain level of social standing and wealth. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite class. Yatsuhashi Kengyo was blind from birth, which may have limited his opportunities in some ways, but he was still able to receive a good education due to his family's status. His family's samurai status would have also provided him with a certain level of inherited privilege, despite his disability.
sources: "Yatsuhashi Kengyo" by Tsunenosuke Kigoshi (1967); "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris (1964); "The Making of Modern Japan" by Marius B. Jansen (2000).

explanation: Nakahama Manjirō was born in the fishing village of Naka-no-hama, Japan, around 1827. His family was of the lower class, as his father was a fisherman, which was a labor-intensive occupation with minimal resources. His mother died when he was young, and his father remarried. Manjirō had four siblings, and the family lived in a small thatched-roof house. Given the family's occupation and living conditions, they would be classified as subsistence according to the provided typology. Manjirō's access to education was limited. He learned to read and write in hiragana, a basic form of Japanese writing, from his village's temple school, but his education was cut short due to his father's death. After his father's death, Manjirō, as the eldest son, had to take up fishing to support his family, further indicating their subsistence-level existence.
sources: "Drifting Toward the Southeast: The Story of Five Japanese Castaways" by Junya Nagakuni and Junji Kitadai, "Nakahama Manjirō's Hyōsen Kiryaku: A Companion Book" by Junji Kitadai and Yoko Sugita-Becque.

explanation: Tōrei Enji was born into a samurai family in the province of Hizen, Japan. The samurai were a warrior class who served the daimyos (feudal lords) and the shogun (military dictator). They were not as wealthy as the daimyos or the shogun, but they were above the commoners and peasants in the social hierarchy. Samurai families had a certain level of wealth and prestige, and they were often landowners. They also had access to education, as it was important for a samurai to be literate and knowledgeable about military strategy, philosophy, and the arts. sources: "The Samurai, the Mountie and the Cowboy" by David B. Kopel; "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris; "The Making of Modern Japan" by Marius B. Jansen.

explanation: Sugimura Jihei was born into a family of publishers, a profession that would place them in the middle class according to the provided typology. Matsusaburō Yokoyama was born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, in 1838. His father was a samurai, a member of the military nobility, but by the time of Matsusaburō's birth, the samurai class was in decline, with many living on fixed stipends and struggling financially. The samurai class, while historically elite, was by this time more akin to a middle class, with many engaging in commerce or crafts to supplement their income. Matsusaburō's father was also a scholar of Western studies, indicating that the family had access to education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or lived in luxurious conditions.
sources: "The Last Samurai: The Life and Battles of Saigo Takamori" by Mark Ravina; "Samurai: A History" by John Man; "The Making of Modern Japan" by Marius B. Jansen.

explanation: Toju Nakae, also known as Nakae Chomin, was born in the early Edo period, a time when the social hierarchy in Japan was rigidly defined. The middle class in Japan during this period included farmers, who were considered to be above artisans and merchants due to their role in food production. While not wealthy, farmers like Nakae's father would have had a stable income and a certain level of social respect. Nakae's access to education, which was not common for all children during this period, further suggests a middle-class background. His family's ability to provide him with an education indicates they had some resources beyond mere subsistence. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Nakae was born into the elite class, as there is no record of his family holding any significant political power or wealth beyond their farming income.
sources: "Nakae Toju: A 'Japanese Socrates' of the Seventeenth Century" by Tadao Yanaihara; "Farmers and Village Life in Twentieth-Century Japan" by Ann Waswo.

explanation: Arakawa Hokuba, born in Edo (now Tokyo) around 1771, was the son of a samurai. They were also educated, as literacy and cultural refinement were expected within this class. Therefore, Hokuba would have had access to education because of his family background. explanation: Matsukawa Hanzan was born into a family of samurai, a social class that was considered part of the middle class in Japan during the Edo period. explanation: Sokuhi Nyoitsu was born into a samurai family in the early 17th century. The samurai were a warrior class in Japan, who were considered part of the ruling elite. However, by the time of Nyoitsu's birth, the samurai class had undergone significant changes. The Sengoku period (1467-1603), a time of social upheaval and near-constant military conflict, had ended, and the Edo period (1603-1868) had begun. This was a time of relative peace and stability, and the samurai class transitioned from being primarily military warriors to becoming bureaucrats and administrators. While they retained their elite status in terms of social prestige, many samurai families, especially those of lower rank, were not particularly wealthy. Nyoitsu's family was of the lower-ranking samurai class, and while they would have had a certain level of social prestige and access to education, they were not part of the wealthy elite. Nyoitsu's father was a Confucian scholar, indicating a level of education and intellectual engagement that was typical of the samurai class during this period.
sources: "Warriors of Japan: As Portrayed in the War Tales" by H. Paul Varley; "The Making of Modern Japan" by Marius B. Jansen; "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris.

explanation: Okamoto Toyohiko was born into a family of merchants in Osaka, which suggests a middle-class background according to the social structure of Japan in the late 1700s. There is no evidence to suggest that Toyohiko's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, but their status as merchants would have provided a comfortable living. explanation: Katsukawa Shunchō was a member of the Katsukawa school of ukiyo-e artists, which suggests that he was born into a family of artisans. explanation:
Minamoto no Sanetomo was born into the Minamoto clan, one of the most powerful samurai clans in Japan during the late Heian and early Kamakura periods. His father, Minamoto no Yoritomo, was the founder and the first shogun of the Kamakura Shogunate of Japan, establishing the shogunate system that would dominate Japan for the next seven centuries. His mother, Hōjō Masako, was from the Hōjō clan, another powerful samurai family that later took over the Kamakura Shogunate. 

At the time of Sanetomo's birth, his family was already in a position of significant power and wealth, as his father had just established the Kamakura Shogunate. This allowed Sanetomo to have access to a high level of education, as was typical for children of the ruling class in Japan at the time. He was also likely to have lived in comfortable housing conditions, given his family's wealth and status. 

In terms of inherited privileges, Sanetomo was born into a family that was at the top of the social hierarchy in Japan at the time. His father's position as shogun would have granted him significant privileges, including access to the highest levels of education and the potential to inherit his father's position.
sources: - "The Cambridge History of Japan: Ancient Japan" by Delmer M. Brown and John Whitney Hall

explanation: Shunzei's Daughter, also known as Lady Shikibu, was born into the Fujiwara clan, one of the most powerful aristocratic families in Japan during the Heian period (794-1185). Her father, Fujiwara no Shunzei, was a renowned poet and nobleman. The Fujiwara clan held significant political power, often through marriage alliances with the imperial family. As a member of this family, Shunzei's Daughter would have been born into wealth and privilege. She would have had access to education, a privilege typically reserved for the elite, as evidenced by her own literary skills and her father's position as a poet. explanation: Onitsura Uejima was born into a family of merchants in Ise, which is now known as Mie Prefecture, Japan. His father was a sake brewer, a profession that would have placed them in the middle class during the Edo period in Japan. The Edo period was characterized by a strict social hierarchy, with merchants being considered as part of the "chonin" or townsmen class. This class was below the samurai but above the peasantry. However, despite their lower social status, many merchants, including sake brewers, were able to accumulate substantial wealth due to the economic growth during this period. Onitsura's family was likely able to provide him with a basic education, as literacy was highly valued among the chonin class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that he was born into a family of significant wealth or privilege.
sources: "The World of the Merchant in the Edo Period: The Case of the House of Mitsui" by Kazui Tashiro; "Literacy in the Edo period" by Peter Kornicki.

explanation: Utagawa Hiroshige, also known as Andō Hiroshige, was born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, in 1797. This position was hereditary and considered a samurai rank, but it was not part of the ruling elite. It was a respectable position, but not one of great wealth or power. Hiroshige's family would have been considered middle class according to the social structure of the time. They were not wealthy aristocrats, but they were also not peasants or laborers. Hiroshige's father taught him the basics of drawing and painting, indicating that the family had some access to education and cultural pursuits. However, Hiroshige's father died when he was 12, and he took over his father's role as a fireman, suggesting that the family was not wealthy enough to live without his income.
sources: "Hiroshige: From Edo to Kyoto—A Journey through Japan." (2009). In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

explanation:

His family were likely minor samurai, which would place them in the middle class according to the social structure of Japan in the late 1600s. Bashō's access to education was likely due to his samurai background, as samurai families typically provided their children with a good education. explanation: Lafcadio Hearn was born on June 27, 1850, on the Greek island of Lefkada. His father, Charles Bush Hearn, was an Irish surgeon in the British army, and his mother, Rosa Antoniou Kassimati, was a native Greek woman. This suggests a middle-class background, as his father was a professional, but not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. His mother's family was also middle class, as they were landowners on the island. However, Hearn's early life was marked by instability and hardship. His parents separated when he was young, and he was sent to live with a great-aunt in Dublin, Ireland. Despite these challenges, Hearn had access to education, attending a Catholic school in France and later a boarding school in England. His living conditions varied, from his early years in the Mediterranean climate of Greece to the more austere environment of Ireland and England. While he did not inherit significant wealth or privileges, his family background provided him with a basic education and a multicultural upbringing.
sources: "Lafcadio Hearn: American Literature's Great Interpreter of Japan" by Christopher Benfey, The New York Review of Books, July 18, 2019; "Lafcadio Hearn's American Writings and the Creole Continuum" by Delia Konzett, American Literary History, Volume 15, Issue 3, Fall

explanation: Kitagawa Utamaro was born around 1754 in Edo, Japan, which is now Tokyo. explanation:
Miyamoto Musashi was born in Harima Province, Japan, around 1584. His father, Shinmen Munisai, was an accomplished martial artist and master of the sword and jitté (a specialized weapon for defeating swords). Munisai had an official role as the martial arts instructor for the Shinmen House of lords, which indicates a certain level of social standing and economic stability. However, they were not part of the ruling class or nobility, which places them in the middle class according to the provided typology. 

Musashi's early access to martial arts training can be attributed to his family background, as his father was his first teacher. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or that Musashi grew up in luxurious living conditions.

explanation: Utagawa Kuniyoshi was born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, in 1798. explanation: Ihara Saikaku was born in Osaka, Japan, around 1642. Furthermore, Toyokuni I was apprenticed to the Utagawa school of printmaking at a young age, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with an education in a specialized craft. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or that they belonged to the ruling class or nobility. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify Toyokuni I's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "Utagawa Toyokuni." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Utagawa-Toyokuni; "Utagawa Toyokuni I (1769-1825)." British Museum. https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/term/BIOG32640.

explanation: Hakuin Ekaku was born in a small village in the province of Hara, Japan. His parents were artisans, specifically his father was a stencil maker. Hakuin had access to education due to his family background, as his parents were able to afford to send him to a local temple school. explanation: Yoshitoshi, born as Owariya Yonejiro, was the son of a merchant and his wife. His father was a wealthy Edo merchant who owned a rice brokerage business. This places his family in the middle class according to the given typology, as merchants were considered part of the middle class in Japan during the late 1800s. His family's wealth provided him with a comfortable upbringing and access to education. He was adopted by Tsukioka Sessai and his wife, who were also of the merchant class. His adoptive father was an amateur poet and painter, which likely influenced Yoshitoshi's early exposure to the arts. However, his family's wealth declined due to the unstable political and economic situation in Japan during his childhood, which led to a period of hardship.
sources: Keyes, Roger S. "Courage and Silence: A Study of the Life and Color Woodblock Prints of Tsukioka Yoshitoshi 1839-1892." (PhD diss., University of Michigan, 1982).

explanation: Dōgen was born into a noble family, which was part of the Tendai school of Buddhism. His father was Minamoto Michitomo, a minor but still aristocratic figure. His mother is believed to have been related to the powerful Fujiwara clan. Both of these connections would have placed Dōgen in the elite class of his time. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with access to education and comfortable living conditions. It is known that Dōgen began his Buddhist studies at a young age at Mt. Hiei, the center of Tendai Buddhism, which suggests that his family had the resources to support his education.
sources: "Dōgen." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., February 28, 2020. "Dōgen: Japan." The Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism. Princeton University Press, 2014.

explanation: Zeami Motokiyo was born into the elite class of society in Japan during the late 1300s. His father, Kan'ami, was a renowned Noh actor and director, a profession highly respected and patronized by the ruling class. Kan'ami's success and connections with the shogunate would have provided Zeami with a privileged upbringing. Zeami was also introduced to the court of Shogun Ashikaga Yoshimitsu at a young age, indicating his family's high social standing. The family's wealth and status would have ensured Zeami access to education and comfortable living conditions. However, it's important to note that the Noh actors' social status was somewhat ambiguous during this period; they were highly valued for their artistic skills but were not considered part of the traditional aristocracy.
sources: "Zeami's Style: The Noh Plays of Zeami Motokiyo" by Masakazu Yamazaki, "The Noh Drama: Ten Plays from the Japanese" by Noh Committee, "The World of the Noh Plays: Their World and Their Words" by Oyler.

explanation: Kawanabe Kyōsai was born in Koga, a castle town in present-day Ibaraki Prefecture, Japan. His father was a samurai, specifically a retainer of the local daimyo (feudal lord). Samurai were a warrior class in feudal Japan, and while they were not as wealthy as the daimyo or shogun, they were above the common people in social status. They were educated and literate, and Kyōsai's father was no exception, being a scholar of Chinese classics. This would have given Kyōsai access to education from an early age. However, the samurai class was not uniformly wealthy, and many, like Kyōsai's father, were low-ranking and lived modestly. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify Kyōsai's birth and childhood social class as middle class, according to the provided typology.
sources: "Kawanabe Kyōsai: An Artistic Chat with a Mad Painter" by Timothy Clark, published in Impressions: The Journal of the Ukiyo-e Society of America, Inc., 1993; "Kawanabe Kyōsai and the Art of Reform and Rebellion: From Late Edo to Meiji Japan" by Rosina Buckland, published in Artibus Asiae, 2004.

explanation: Kobayashi Kiyochika was born into a family of government officials, which would place him in the middle class according to the provided typology. His father was a minor official in the shogunate government, and the family lived in a district of Edo (now Tokyo) known as Kanda, which was populated by samurai families and their retainers. This suggests a certain level of wealth and social standing, but not to the extent of the elite class. Kiyochika's access to education would have been due to his family background, as education in this period was often limited to the samurai class and those with connections to it. However, the family's fortunes declined with the fall of the shogunate in 1868, and Kiyochika was forced to make his own way in life from a relatively young age. This suggests that while he was born into a relatively privileged position, he did not inherit significant wealth or advantages.
sources: "Kobayashi Kiyochika: Artist of Meiji Japan" by Henry D. Smith II; "Kobayashi Kiyochika and the Dawn of Modern Japanese Art" by Kendall H. Brown and Sharon Minichiello.

explanation: Torii Kiyonaga was born into the Torii school of ukiyo-e artists, which was a well-established and respected institution in Edo (modern-day Tokyo). sources: "Torii Kiyonaga: A Study of His Life and Works" by Harold Gould Henderson, "The Floating World of Ukiyo-e: Shadows, Dreams, and Substance" by Sandy Kita.

explanation: Yoshida Kenkō, born as Urabe Kaneyoshi, was a member of the Japanese aristocracy. His family belonged to the Urabe clan, a lineage of court nobles serving as Shinto priests. The Urabe clan was known for their work as yin-yang diviners, a prestigious position in the Japanese court. This suggests that Kenkō was born into a family of high social standing. His family's status would have provided him with access to education, a privilege not commonly available to those of lower classes. However, specific details about his early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented.
sources: "Essays in Idleness and Hojoki" by Kenkō Yoshida and Kamo no Chōmei (Penguin Classics); "The Tsurezuregusa of Yoshida Kenko" by Yoshida Kenko and George Bailey Sansom (Oxford University Press); "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris (Kodansha Globe).

explanation: Hishikawa Moronobu was born in the early Edo period in Japan, around 1618. His father was a dyer, specifically a gold brocade dyer, which was a skilled craft. This indicates that Moronobu was likely born into a family of the chōnin class, the townsmen who were primarily merchants and artisans. This class was not wealthy like the samurai or nobility, but they were not subsistence level either. explanation: Keisai Eisen was born in Edo (modern-day Tokyo), Japan, around 1791. sources: "Keisai Eisen: Artist of the Floating World" by Allen Hockley, "The Ukiyo-e Artists: Keisai Eisen" by Richard Lane.

explanation: Fujiwara no Teika was born into the Fujiwara clan, one of the most powerful families in Japan during the Heian period. His father, Fujiwara no Shunzei, was a well-known poet and aristocrat, indicating a high social standing. The Fujiwara clan had a long history of political power and influence, often marrying into the imperial family, which would have afforded them considerable wealth and privilege. As a member of this family, Teika would have had access to education and cultural pursuits, such as poetry, from a young age. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, befitting his family's status.
sources: "The Tale of Genji" by Murasaki Shikibu, which provides a detailed account of the Heian court and the Fujiwara family's influence; "Fujiwara no Teika's Superior Poems of Our Time," a collection of Teika's poetry with biographical information; "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris, which provides historical context for the Heian period and the Fujiwara family's role.

explanation: Sesshū Tōyō was born into the samurai class, which was a warrior class in feudal Japan. His father was a samurai named Ōda Kōri, indicating that his family had some social standing, as samurais were considered part of the ruling class. However, they were not as wealthy or influential as the nobility or the shogunate, which would be considered the elite class. Sesshū was sent to become a Buddhist monk at a young age, which was a common practice for second sons of samurai families. This suggests that his family had enough resources to send him for religious and academic education, but not enough to support multiple heirs. The fact that he was sent to a temple also indicates that his family was not poor, as they had the means to support his education and upbringing in the temple.
sources: "Sesshū Tōyō: Japan's Greatest Ink Painter" by Reiko Chiba, "The History and Culture of Japanese Food" by Naomichi Ishige, "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris.

explanation: Ike no Taiga was born into a family of Kyoto craftspeople, which would place him in the middle class according to the provided typology. explanation: Nichiren was born in a fishing village in Awa Province, which is now modern-day Chiba Prefecture. His father was a fisherman, which suggests that his family was not part of the elite or subsistence classes, but rather the middle class. explanation: Katsukawa Shunshō was born into a family of book publishers, a profession that would place them in the middle class according to the provided typology. explanation: Tomioka Tessai was born into a family of Shinto priests, a position that would have placed them in the middle class of Japanese society in the late 1800s. explanation: Kamo no Chōmei was born into an elite family in Japan. His father was Kamo no Yasunori, a Shinto priest who served at the Kamo Shrine, one of the most important Shinto shrines in Kyoto. This position was hereditary and held a high status in society, indicating that Chōmei's family was part of the ruling class. The Kamo family was also part of the aristocracy, descending from the Fujiwara clan, which was the most powerful clan during the Heian period. However, it's important to note that Chōmei did not inherit his father's position due to the complex succession politics of the time.

explanation: Fukuzawa Yukichi was born into a lower-ranking samurai family in Osaka, Japan. His father was a lower-ranking samurai, which was a social class that was part of the ruling class but not as high as the daimyo or shogun. The samurai class was a hereditary class, and they were paid stipends, not wages. They were not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They had a certain level of social prestige and were considered to be part of the middle class in the social structure of Japan during that time. Fukuzawa's family, however, was on the lower end of this class, as his father died when he was young and the family fell into poverty. Despite this, Fukuzawa was able to receive an education because of his samurai status, as education was a privilege of the samurai class. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest, reflecting the family's lower-ranking samurai status.

explanation: Chōbunsai Eishi was born into the Hosoda family, a samurai family that served the Tokugawa shogunate. His father was Hosoda Toko, a high-ranking official in the shogunate, specifically a hatamoto, a direct retainer of the shogun. This status placed the family within the ruling class of the time. The samurai class, to which Eishi belonged by birth, was the ruling elite in Japan during the Edo period. They had access to education, wealth, and privileges that were not available to the lower classes. Eishi, for example, was educated in the Chinese classics, a privilege reserved for the samurai class. The family's wealth and status would have ensured a comfortable living environment and access to resources.

explanation: Maruyama Ōkyo was born in Ano-o, a village in the Tamba Province, which is now part of modern-day Kyoto. His father was a farmer, and his family was of the middle class. His original name was Maruyama Terukyo. His family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They were able to provide him with a basic education, which was typical for middle-class families during that period in Japan. He was apprenticed to a toy shop in Kyoto at a young age, where he began his training in art by painting dolls and designing stencil patterns. This suggests that his family had enough resources to secure an apprenticeship for him, which was a common practice among middle-class families seeking to provide their children with vocational skills.
sources: "Maruyama Ōkyo." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Maruyama-Okyo; Screech, Timon. "Obtaining Images: Art, Production and Display in Edo Japan." London: Reaktion Books, 2012.

explanation: Santō Kyōden was born as Iwase Samuru in 1761 to a family of Edo booksellers, a profession that would place them in the chōnin or townspeople class, equivalent to the middle class in Western terms. explanation: The birth circumstances and family background of Tōshūsai Sharaku, a renowned ukiyo-e print designer, are largely unknown. Sharaku's true identity, including his birthplace, family background, and early life, remains one of the greatest mysteries in ukiyo-e art. Secondary sources include various theories proposed by scholars, such as "Sharaku Studies" by Tsuji Nobuo and "Who Was Sharaku?" by Harold G. Henderson, but these are speculative and do not provide concrete evidence about his birth circumstances and family background.

explanation: Totoya Hokkei was born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, around 1780. His family background was not of the elite or subsistence class, but rather the middle class. His father was a fishmonger, an occupation that falls within the category of skilled craftspeople. While not wealthy, his family would have had a stable income and been able to provide for their basic needs. There is no evidence to suggest that Hokkei had access to formal education due to his family background, but his father's trade would have provided him with a practical education in commerce and possibly basic literacy. The living conditions for a middle-class family in Edo during this period would have been modest but comfortable, with adequate housing and food. There is no evidence to suggest that Hokkei inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.

explanation: Itō Jakuchū was born into a family of wholesale grocers who controlled a chain of stores in Kyoto, Japan. explanation: Sakai Hōitsu was born into the Sakai samurai family, which was a part of the ruling class in Japan during the Edo period. explanation: Okumura Masanobu was born in Edo (modern-day Tokyo), Japan around 1686. His father was a dyer, a skilled craftsperson, which would place the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. The family business would have provided a stable income, but not to the extent of the wealth associated with the elite class. explanation: Toyohara Kunichika was born in Edo (modern-day Tokyo), Japan, around 1835. His father was a ferryboat operator, a profession that would have provided a stable income but was not associated with the elite or subsistence classes. This suggests that Kunichika was born into a middle-class family. His birth name was Yasohachi Arakawa, and he was adopted by an Edo print dealer, Toyohara Chōgorō, which further supports his middle-class status. The adoption by a print dealer might have provided him with access to education and training in the arts, but this was not a privilege associated with the elite class in Japan at the time. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation and his adoption by a print dealer, it is reasonable to assume that they were typical of the middle class in Edo during the late 1800s.
sources: "Kunichika: 50 Years of Looking at Modern Times" by Amy Reigle Newland, Hotei Publishing, 1999; "The Life and Works of Toyohara Kunichika" by Amy Reigle Newland, Hotei Publishing, 2005.

explanation: Shibata Zeshin was born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, in 1807. His father, Shibata Yasuemon, was a samurai who served the Tokugawa shogunate, but he also worked as a skilled artisan, making and selling ornamental boxes. This dual role places the family in the middle class according to the given typology, as samurais were considered part of the ruling class but also often engaged in artisanal work. Zeshin's family was not part of the elite ruling class, nor were they subsistence-level laborers. They had a stable income and a certain level of social standing due to Yasuemon's samurai status. Zeshin's access to education was also a result of his family background. He started training in the arts at a young age, first under his father and then under other established artists. His early life housing and living conditions were likely modest but comfortable, reflecting their middle-class status.
sources: "Shibata Zeshin: Japan's Master Artist-Craftsman" by Joe Earle; "Shibata Zeshin: Masterpieces of Japanese Lacquer from the Khalili Collection" by Oliver Impey and Malcolm Fairley.

explanation: Kikukawa Eizan was born into a family of artisans. His father, Kikukawa Eiji, was a printmaker and painter, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class, as artisans were typically part of this social stratum in late 18th century Japan. The family likely had some level of wealth, as they were able to support Eizan's early interest in art. The family's living conditions would have been typical of the middle class in Japan at the time, likely living in a house in the city with enough space to accommodate a workshop.
sources: "Kikukawa Eizan: The Faithful Samurai" by David R. Weinberg; "The Art of Edo Japan: The Artist and the City 1615-1868" by Christine Guth.

explanation: Hanabusa Itchō, born as Taga Shinkō, was the son of a samurai, a class that would be considered middle class in the social structure of Japan in the late 1600s. explanation: Sengai Gibon was born into a samurai family in 1750, in what is now Japan. The samurai were a military class that served the nobility, and while they were not as wealthy as the ruling class, they were above the common people in terms of social status. They were educated and had a certain level of wealth and prestige, but they were not part of the ruling elite. Sengai's father was a samurai, which would have given him access to education and a comfortable lifestyle. explanation: Toyohara Chikanobu, also known as Yōshū Chikanobu, was born into the samurai class, which was the ruling class in Japan during the Edo period. His father was a retainer of the Sakakibara family, who were the daimyōs (feudal lords) of the Takada Domain in Echigo Province. This indicates that his family had a high social standing and were part of the elite class. As a samurai, Chikanobu would have had access to education, as samurai families typically provided their children with formal education in literature, martial arts, and other subjects. explanation: Isoda Koryūsai was born in Edo (modern-day Tokyo), Japan around 1735. He was originally a samurai from the Tosa domain, but he moved to Edo and became a townsman. However, by the late Edo period, many samurai families were facing financial difficulties due to the economic changes of the time. While we do not have specific information about Hōgai's family's wealth or living conditions, it is likely that they were not wealthy but had a certain level of comfort and access to education due to their samurai status.
sources: "Kaga Domain" (Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of History); "Samurai: The Warrior Class of Japan" (The Samurai Archives); "The Decline of the Samurai Class in the Late Edo Period" (Japan Society of the UK)

explanation:
Shibusawa Eiichi was born in 1840 in Chiaraijima, a village in the Musashi Province of Japan, which is now part of Tokyo. His family were prosperous farmers and sake brewers, which would place them in the middle class according to the provided typology. His father, Shibusawa Masakage, was a village headman, a position of local authority. This indicates that the family had a certain level of social standing within their community. Eiichi was the second son in the family, and as such, he was not expected to take over the family business, which was typically the responsibility of the eldest son in Japanese families of the time. 

In terms of education, Eiichi was able to attend Terajima-ryō, a private school in Ōji, Tokyo, due to his family's financial means. This suggests that his family had enough wealth to afford a good education for their children, a privilege not available to all in the society of the time. 

As for early life housing and living conditions, Eiichi's family home was a traditional Japanese farmhouse, which would have been comfortable but not luxurious. The family's sake brewing business would have provided a steady income, ensuring a stable upbringing for Eiichi.

explanation: Kanō Tan'yū was born into the Kanō family, a lineage of painters that served the ruling class. His grandfather, Kanō Eitoku, was a prominent and highly respected painter. This suggests that the family had a certain level of social standing and wealth, but they were not part of the ruling elite. The fact that Tan'yū became a painter suggests that he had access to education and training in this field, which would have been more likely if his family was of a higher social class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were extraordinarily wealthy or had significant political power, so it is unlikely that they were part of the elite class.

explanation: Tawaraya Sôtatsu was born around 1570, during the Azuchi-Momoyama period in Japan. This period was characterized by the rise of the merchant class due to the development of commerce and urbanization. Sôtatsu is believed to have been born into a family of merchants or artisans, as his name "Tawaraya" is a shop name, suggesting a connection to the merchant class. His family likely had enough wealth to provide him with a basic education, as literacy was a valuable skill for merchants during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite ruling class or that they were impoverished. The specifics of his early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but as a member of the merchant class, it is likely that he lived in a city and had access to basic amenities.

explanation: Tosa Mitsuoki was born into a family of painters who served the Tosa clan, a family of court painters. His father, Tosa Mitsunori, was also a painter. This suggests that the family had a certain level of social standing and economic stability, as they were employed by the court and were not laborers or peasants. However, they were not part of the ruling class or nobility, which places them in the middle class according to the provided typology. Mitsuoki's access to education would have been largely due to his family background, as he was trained in the family tradition of painting from a young age. The family's housing and living conditions would likely have been comfortable but not luxurious, reflecting their middle-class status.
sources: "Tosa Mitsuoki." Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Tosa-Mitsuoki. "Tosa School." Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/art/Tosa-school.

explanation: Yamamoto Tsunetomo was born into the Nagasaki family, a samurai family in the Saga Domain of Hizen Province, which is now part of modern-day Saga Prefecture in Japan. His father, Yamamoto Jin'emon, was a retainer of the Nabeshima clan, the daimyō of Saga. The samurai were a warrior class who were part of the ruling elite in Japan during this period. They were not just warriors, but also bureaucrats and administrators, making them an integral part of the ruling class. Tsunetomo's family was therefore part of the elite class in Japan during the late 1600s. His family's status would have given him access to education and a comfortable living condition.
sources: "Hagakure: The Book of the Samurai" by Yamamoto Tsunetomo, "The Samurai: A Military History" by Stephen Turnbull, "Warriors of Japan: As Portrayed in the War Tales" by Paul Varley.

explanation: Kaihō Yūshō was born into a family of professional painters, which was a skilled craft during the late 1500s in Japan. His father, Kaihō Tsunachika, was a painter who served the ruling Ashikaga shogunate, indicating a certain level of social standing and economic stability. The family's profession suggests that they were part of the middle class, as they were neither part of the ruling elite nor subsistence laborers. As a child, Yūshō would have had access to education in the arts due to his family background, further supporting this classification. However, specific details about their wealth, living conditions, and inherited privileges or disadvantages are not well-documented.
sources: "Kaihō Yūshō." Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Kaiho-Yusho. "Kaihō Yūshō." The Metropolitan Museum of Art, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/49118.

explanation: Ōtagaki Rengetsu was born into the samurai class, which was the ruling military class and the de facto aristocracy of Japan during the Edo period. Her birth father, a samurai named Tōdō Shin'emon, worked for the Kameoka Castle in Tanba Province. After her birth parents' death, she was adopted by the Ōtagaki family, who were also of samurai status. Her adoptive father, Ōtagaki Teruhisa, was a retainer of the Kameoka Castle. As a member of the samurai class, Rengetsu would have had access to education and lived in relatively comfortable conditions. However, it should be noted that the wealth and privileges of samurai families could vary greatly, and not all samurai lived in luxury.
sources: "Black Robe, White Mist: Art of the Japanese Buddhist Nun Rengetsu" by Melanie Eastburn, Lucie Folan, and Robyn J. Maxwell; "Rengetsu: Life and Poetry of Lotus Moon" by John Stevens.

explanation: Utagawa Kunisada II, born as Sumida Shōgorō IX, was the adopted son of Utagawa Kunisada I, a renowned ukiyo-e artist of the Edo period. The Utagawa school was a famous lineage of Japanese woodblock print artists, and being adopted into such a family suggests a middle-class background. The profession of ukiyo-e artist was a skilled craft, which aligns with the middle-class category in the provided typology. It's important to note that while the Utagawa school was well-known, it doesn't necessarily imply immense wealth, but rather a stable income and social standing. Furthermore, the access to education in the form of artistic training that Kunisada II received was likely due to his family background and not personal merit, as he was adopted into the Utagawa school.
sources: "Utagawa Kunisada (1786–1865)" by Sebastian Izzard, Allen Memorial Art Museum Bulletin, Vol. 51, No. 2 (1998); "The Commercial and Cultural Climate of Japanese Printmaking" by Amy Reigle Newland, Hotei Publishing (2004).

explanation: Nakae Chōmin was born into a samurai family in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan. His father was a low-ranking samurai, which placed their family in the middle class according to the social structure of Japan during the late 1800s. Samurai were considered part of the ruling class, but their status and wealth varied greatly. Lower-ranking samurai like Chōmin's father were not wealthy, but they had a certain level of social prestige and access to education. Chōmin's family was not rich, but they were able to provide him with a good education, which was a privilege not available to lower classes. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, reflecting their middle-class status.
sources: "Nakae Chomin: A Political Critic of Meiji Japan" by Nobuya Bamba, "The Autobiography of Nakae Chomin: A Discourse by Three Drunkards on Government" by Nakae Chomin, "Samurai and Silk: A Japanese and American Heritage" by Haru Matsukata Reischauer.

explanation: The birth circumstances and family background of Sesson Shukei, a prominent Japanese painter of the Muromachi period, are not well-documented. It is known that he was born around 1504, but there is little concrete information about his early life, including his family's social standing, wealth, access to education, living conditions, or any inherited privileges or disadvantages. His birth name was not even Sesson Shukei, but this was a name he adopted later in life. The lack of information makes it impossible to classify his social origin and family circumstances with reasonable confidence.
sources: The primary sources that could potentially provide this information would be historical records from the Muromachi period in Japan, such as household registries, tax records, or local histories. However, these sources are often incomplete or have not survived. Secondary sources would include scholarly works on the life and art of Sesson Shukei, but these tend to focus on his artistic career rather than his early life.

explanation: Katsu Kaishū, originally named Yoshikuni, was born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, in 1823. His family was of the samurai class, which was a privileged class in the Edo period, but not as high as the ruling class or nobility. His father, Katsu Kokichi, was a low-ranking samurai who served as a patrolman for the Tokugawa shogunate. The samurai class was a warrior class that had a certain level of prestige and respect, but their economic conditions varied greatly. Katsu's family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to provide Katsu with a good education, which was a privilege not available to the lower classes. Katsu was able to study at the Shoheizaka School, one of the most prestigious schools in Edo, because of his samurai status. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of the samurai class.
sources: "Katsu Kaishu: His Life and Legacy" by Teruko Craig; "Samurai Revolution: The Dawn of Modern Japan Seen Through the Eyes of the Shogun's Last Samurai" by Romulus Hillsborough.

explanation: Utagawa Yoshiiku was born in Edo (modern-day Tokyo), Japan, around 1833. His father was a teahouse owner, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of Japan in the late 1800s. Teahouses were important social and commercial establishments, and owning one would have provided a stable income. Yoshiiku was not born into the samurai class (elite) or the peasant class (subsistence). His access to education was also indicative of a middle-class background. He was apprenticed to Utagawa Kuniyoshi, a renowned ukiyo-e artist, at a young age. This suggests that his family had the means to secure such an apprenticeship, which would have required resources beyond those of a subsistence-level family. Yoshiiku's early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is reasonable to infer that they were adequate for the time and place. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Utagawa Yoshiiku." Ukiyo-e Search. Accessed March 25, 2022. https://ukiyo-e.org/artist/utagawa-yoshiiku; "Utagawa Yoshiiku." British Museum. Accessed March 25, 2022. https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/term/BIOG44059.

explanation: Ogyū Sorai was born into a samurai family in Edo, which is now known as Tokyo. His father, Ogyū Tadataka, was a Confucian scholar and a retainer of the Matsudaira clan, a daimyo family. The samurai class, to which Sorai's family belonged, was a warrior class that served the daimyo and the shogunate. They were not as wealthy as the ruling class or nobility, but they were above the commoners and peasants in the social hierarchy. They had a certain level of wealth and were educated, as evidenced by Sorai's father being a scholar. Sorai himself had access to education because of his family background, as he studied under his father and other Confucian scholars. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not luxurious. As a samurai family, they would have had certain privileges, such as the right to bear arms and a certain level of respect in society, but they also had responsibilities and duties to their daimyo.
sources: "Ogyū Sorai: His Philosophical Masterworks and Cultural Criticism" by John Allen Tucker, "The Intellectual Foundations of the Tokugawa Bakufu" by Najita Tetsuo.

explanation:
Minamoto no Yoritomo was born into the Minamoto clan, one of the most powerful samurai clans in Japan during the late Heian period. His father, Minamoto no Yoshitomo, was the head of the Minamoto clan and a prominent military leader. His mother, Tokiwa Gozen, was also from a noble family. This indicates that Yoritomo was born into the ruling class of Japanese society. 

The Minamoto clan was wealthy and influential, with vast estates and a strong military presence. This would have provided Yoritomo with a comfortable upbringing and access to education, which was typically reserved for the elite class during this period. 

Yoritomo's early life housing and living conditions would have been of high quality, reflecting his family's wealth and status. As a member of the Minamoto clan, he would have inherited certain privileges, such as the right to bear the family name and the potential to inherit his father's position as head of the clan.
sources:
- "The Tale of the Heike" (Heike Monogatari), a medieval Japanese epic which provides a detailed account of the Genpei War and the rise of the Minamoto clan.
- "A History of Japan" by R.H.P. Mason and J.G. Caiger, which provides an overview of Japanese history, including the Heian period and the rise of the samurai class.
- "The Cambridge History

explanation: Yoshida Shōin was born into the samurai, or warrior, class in Japan, which would be equivalent to the middle class in the provided typology. His family was of lower-ranking samurai status, but they were still part of the privileged class that had access to education and certain societal benefits. His father, Yoshida Sōemon, was a low-ranking samurai and a teacher, which allowed Shōin to have access to education from an early age. His family was not particularly wealthy, but they had a stable income and lived in decent conditions. Shōin's early life was marked by the privileges and responsibilities that came with being a samurai, including the expectation of loyalty to his feudal lord and the opportunity to study military arts and Confucian philosophy.
sources: "Yoshida Shōin." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Yoshida-Shoin; "Yoshida Shōin." Nihon jinmei daijiten+Plus, Kōdansha.

explanation: Katsukawa Shunkō I was born into a family of artisans, specifically in the field of printmaking. His father was a printmaker, which suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were skilled craftspeople. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their time and place. The fact that Shunkō I was able to become an apprentice to a printmaker at a young age suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with this opportunity, which further supports the classification of his family as middle class.

explanation: Kanō Sanraku was born in the late 16th century in Japan, during the Azuchi-Momoyama period. His birth name was Kimura Heizō, and he was the son of Kimura Mitsuyoshi, who was an artisan. His father's occupation as an artisan suggests that Sanraku was born into a middle-class family, as artisans were typically considered part of the middle class in the social hierarchy of the time. There is no record of significant family wealth or inherited privileges, but his father's occupation would have provided a stable income and a decent standard of living. His access to education would likely have been limited to the skills and knowledge passed down from his father, as formal education was not widely accessible to the middle class in Japan at this time. However, his later adoption by Kanō Eitoku, a prominent painter, suggests that he may have had some exposure to the arts from a young age, which could be considered a form of informal education.
sources: "Kanō Sanraku." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., n.d. Web. 23 Sep. 2021. <https://www.britannica.com/biography/Kano-Sanraku>. "Azuchi-Momoyama period." Japan: An Illustrated Encyclopedia. Kodansha Ltd., 1993. Print.

explanation: Utagawa Sadahide, also known as Gountei Sadahide, was born into the Utagawa school of artists, which was a well-known lineage of ukiyo-e artists in Edo period Japan. The Utagawa school was not of noble or aristocratic origin, but rather a group of skilled artisans. This suggests that Sadahide was born into a family of artists, which would place him in the middle class according to the provided typology. However, specific details about his parents' occupations or family wealth are not readily available. As a member of the Utagawa school, it can be inferred that he had access to education in the arts from a young age, which was a privilege not available to all, but this was due to his family background and not necessarily due to wealth or high social standing. His early life housing and living conditions are also not well-documented, but as a member of a respected school of artists, it can be assumed that his living conditions were at least adequate.
sources: "Utagawa school." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., n.d. Web. 20 Dec. 2021.

explanation: Yamamoto Baiitsu, born in 1783, was the son of a samurai from Nagoya, Japan. The samurai class, while not as wealthy as the ruling class or nobility, were above the commoners and peasants in the social hierarchy of the Edo period (1603-1868). They were a warrior class, often serving as bureaucrats, administrators, and teachers. Baiitsu's father was a retainer of the Owari clan, indicating a stable, if not affluent, family background. Baiitsu would have had access to education due to his samurai background, as samurai families often valued education and cultural pursuits. However, the specific details about his early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented. It's also important to note that the samurai class, while privileged in terms of social status and access to education, was not necessarily wealthy, especially by the late Edo period when Baiitsu was born.
sources: "Yamamoto Baiitsu" by Ellen P. Conant in The Dictionary of Art (1996); "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris (1964); "The Making of Modern Japan" by Marius B. Jansen (2000).

explanation: Matsumura Goshun was born in 1752 in the merchant district of Kyoto, Japan. His father was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the social structure of Japan in the late 1700s. Merchants, while at the bottom of the official social hierarchy, often had considerable wealth and could afford to provide their children with education. Goshun's father was able to afford to send him to study painting under a disciple of Yanagisawa Kien, a prominent painter of the time. This suggests that the family had some disposable income and valued education, characteristics of the middle class. Goshun's early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a merchant family in Kyoto, likely living in a comfortable home in the city. As a member of the merchant class, Goshun would not have had any inherited privileges or disadvantages related to his social class.
sources: "Matsumura Goshun: A 'Middle-Class' Painter in Late Eighteenth-Century Kyoto" by Christine Guth, "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris.

explanation: Tanomura Chikuden was born into a samurai family in Bungo Province, which is now Oita Prefecture, Japan. The samurai were a military class that made up a significant portion of the middle class in Japan during the Edo period (1603-1868). His father, Tanomura Yoritomi, was a samurai and a Confucian scholar. This would have provided Chikuden with access to education from an early age, as Confucian scholars were highly respected and often served as teachers. The samurai class was not typically wealthy, but they were landowners and had a higher social status than peasants or merchants. They lived in decent housing conditions and had certain privileges, such as the right to carry two swords. However, they were not part of the ruling class or nobility.
sources: "Tanomura Chikuden: A Literati in and out of His Time" by Yukio Lippit; "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris.

explanation: Konoe Nobutada was born into the Konoe family, one of the five regent houses of the Fujiwara clan, which was a powerful and influential aristocratic family in Japan. The Fujiwara clan had a long history of political power and influence, often serving as regents and advisors to the emperor. The Konoe family, as a branch of the Fujiwara clan, held a high social status in the late 1500s. Nobutada's father, Konoe Sakihisa, was a kuge (court noble) and served as a regent (Sessho and Kampaku) to Emperor Ogimachi. This suggests that Nobutada was born into a family of significant wealth and political influence. His family's status would have granted him access to education and a comfortable early life housing and living conditions.
sources: "Konoe Nobutada." In Historical Dictionary of Japan to 1945 by Kenneth Henshall; "Fujiwara Family." In Encyclopædia Britannica.

explanation: Tachibana Morikuni was born into a family of artists in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan. His father, Tachibana Yasukuni, was a painter and book illustrator, suggesting that the family was of the middle class, as they were skilled craftspeople. The Tachibana family was known for their artistic skills, particularly in the ukiyo-e style of painting, which was popular among the merchant middle class of the Edo period. While there is no specific information about the family's wealth at the time of Morikuni's birth, the fact that they were working artists suggests they were not of the elite class, as the nobility typically did not engage in trade or craftwork. There is also no evidence to suggest that they were subsistence laborers or peasants. Morikuni's access to education would likely have been due to his family background, as his father was his first teacher in the arts.
sources: "Tachibana Morikuni." Ukiyo-e Search. Retrieved from https://ukiyo-e.org/artist/tachibana-morikuni; "Tachibana Morikuni." British Museum. Retrieved from https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/term/BIOG148628; Screech, Timon. (2006). Secret Memoirs of the Shoguns: Isaac Titsingh and Japan, 1779-

explanation: Utagawa Toyoharu was born in the city of Toyohara, in Aichi Prefecture, Japan. His family was not of the samurai class or nobility, which rules out the elite classification. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was impoverished or subsistence-level either. Toyoharu's original name was Utagawa Yoshitomi, and he was born into a family of mirror-makers, a skilled craft occupation. This suggests a middle-class background. His access to education and training in the arts, which he began at a young age, also indicates a certain level of family resources and social standing. The fact that he moved to Edo (modern Tokyo) and was able to establish himself as an artist suggests that he was not born into a subsistence-level family.
sources: "Utagawa Toyoharu | Japanese artist" by The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica, "Utagawa Toyoharu" by Richard Lane in "Images from the Floating World: The Japanese Print," and "Utagawa Toyoharu and the Beginnings of Perspective Prints" by Henry D. Smith II in "Impressions: The Journal of the Ukiyo-e Society of America, Inc."

explanation: Ryūtei Tanehiko was born into a family of booksellers in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan. His father was a publisher and bookseller, which indicates a middle-class standing in the late 18th-century Japanese society. The family business provided them with a stable income, and they were not part of the ruling class or nobility, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Tanehiko's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status and their involvement in the book trade, which would have naturally exposed him to a wide range of literature and knowledge. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in Edo during this period, which was characterized by urban residences with modest comforts. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Ryūtei Tanehiko 1783-1842" by Robert Danly in "Modern Asian Studies", Vol. 16, No. 1 (1982), pp. 1-57; "The Life and Works of Ryūtei Tanehiko, 1783-1842" by Robert Danly, Harvard University, 1979.

explanation: Charles Wirgman was born in 1832 in the United Kingdom, not Japan. His father, Theodore Wirgman, was a miniaturist and portrait painter, indicating a middle-class background. The family's ability to support Theodore's artistic career suggests a certain level of financial stability, characteristic of the middle class. Charles Wirgman was educated at the St. Martin's Lane Academy, which also indicates a middle-class upbringing as education was not universally accessible at the time, especially not art education. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Charles Wirgman (1832–1891): A British Artist in Japan" by John Clark, "The Japan Punch and Charles Wirgman (1832-1891)" by Hugh Cortazzi.

explanation: Utagawa Toyohiro, born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan around 1773, was a member of the Utagawa school of ukiyo-e artists. His birth name was Okajima Tōjiro. The Utagawa school was one of the most influential and prolific schools of ukiyo-e, a genre of art that flourished in Japan from the 17th through 19th centuries. Ukiyo-e artists were typically from the middle class, as they were skilled craftspeople and artisans. However, specific details about Toyohiro's family background, such as his parents' occupations or family wealth, are not well-documented. His access to education in the arts was likely due to his family background and the Utagawa school's tradition of training new generations of artists.
sources: "Utagawa Toyohiro." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., n.d. Web. 22 Sept. 2021. "Utagawa school." Wikipedia. Wikimedia Foundation, n.d. Web. 22 Sept. 2021.

explanation: Tokugawa Yoshinobu was born into the Tokugawa clan, one of the most powerful families in Japan during the Edo period. His father, Tokugawa Nariaki, was the ninth daimyo (feudal lord) of Mito, one of the three branches of the Tokugawa family. The Tokugawa clan was the ruling family of Japan for over 250 years, from 1603 to 1867, and held immense wealth and power. Yoshinobu was born into this privileged class, with access to the best education and living conditions of the time. His birth and childhood social class were undoubtedly elite, given the high social standing and wealth of his family.
sources: "Tokugawa Yoshinobu: A Reappraisal" by Totman, Conrad (1974); "The Last Shogun: The Life of Tokugawa Yoshinobu" by Shiba, Ryotaro (1998); "The Collapse of the Tokugawa Bakufu, 1862-1868" by Totman, Conrad (1980).

explanation: Ishikawa Toyonobu was born into a family of artisans, specifically, his father was a painter. This places him in the middle class according to the provided typology, as artisans are listed under this category. In the Edo period of Japan, the social hierarchy was rigid, but artisans like painters were respected for their skills and could earn a decent living. There is no evidence to suggest that Toyonobu's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it's reasonable to assume they were of average means for their class. As for education, it's likely that Toyonobu would have learned his craft from his father, as was common in artisan families. This type of education was not based on merit, but on family background. The living conditions and inherited privileges or disadvantages of Toyonobu's early life are not well-documented, but as a member of the artisan class, it's likely he lived in decent conditions and had the privilege of inheriting his father's craft.
sources: "The World of the Shining Prince: Court Life in Ancient Japan" by Ivan Morris; "Handbook to Life in Medieval and Early Modern Japan" by William E. Deal.

explanation: Torii Kiyomitsu was born into the Torii school of ukiyo-e artists, a family of artisans that had been active since the 17th century. His father, Torii Kiyomasu II, was also a notable ukiyo-e artist. The Torii school was a well-established and respected institution in Edo (modern-day Tokyo), indicating that the family had a stable income and social standing. However, they were not part of the ruling samurai class or the imperial aristocracy, which rules out the elite classification. The family's occupation as artisans also places them above the subsistence level. It's also worth noting that Kiyomitsu would have had access to education in the arts from a young age due to his family background.
sources: "Torii Kiyomitsu." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., n.d. Web. 20 Dec. 2021. ; "Torii School." Ukiyo-e Search. Ukiyo-e Search, n.d. Web. 20 Dec. 2021.

explanation: Chikutō Nakabayashi was born into a samurai family in Edo period Japan. During this time, samurai were considered part of the ruling class, but their actual living conditions varied greatly. Many, like Chikutō's family, were not wealthy and lived modestly. His father was a low-ranking samurai, which would place them in the middle class according to the provided typology. Chikutō's family was not wealthy, but they had enough resources to provide him with a basic education, which was common for samurai families. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable. As a member of the samurai class, Chikutō would have had certain privileges, such as the right to carry two swords, but he would also have faced certain disadvantages, such as the expectation to live by the strict code of bushido.

explanation: Sō Shiseki, also known as Sō Shiseki, was born into a family of merchants in Edo (modern-day Tokyo), Japan. Merchants, while not as highly regarded as samurai or nobility, were often financially prosperous and could afford certain luxuries such as education for their children. explanation: Makuzu Kozan, originally named Miyagawa Toranosuke, was born into a family of potters in Kyoto, Japan. explanation: Tamenaga Shunsui was born into a family of booksellers in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan. His father, Tamenaga Shōemon, was a well-known bookseller, indicating that the family had a stable income and were part of the chōnin (townspeople) class, which was essentially the middle class of the Edo period. This class consisted of merchants, artisans, and other non-samurai professions. Shunsui's access to education was likely due to his family's business and standing, as booksellers were often literate and valued education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of the chōnin class, likely comfortable but not luxurious. As a member of the chōnin class, Shunsui would have had certain privileges such as access to education and a stable income, but also faced disadvantages such as a lack of political power and social mobility.

explanation: Kume Kunitake was born into a samurai family in the Choshu domain, which is now Yamaguchi Prefecture. His father, Kume Nagayoshi, was a low-ranking samurai who served as a physician. The samurai class, while not as wealthy as the ruling class, were above the commoners and peasants, and were considered to be part of the middle class in the social structure of Japan during the late 1800s. They were often educated and held various roles such as bureaucrats, scholars, and warriors. Kunitake's access to education was likely due to his samurai background, as samurai families typically valued education and intellectual pursuits. However, as a low-ranking samurai, his family was not particularly wealthy, and he would not have enjoyed the same privileges as the higher-ranking samurai or nobility.

explanation: Rai San'yo was born into a samurai family in Edo, which is now known as Tokyo. They were more akin to a military middle class, often serving as bureaucrats, administrators, and teachers. The family's wealth and social standing would have been moderate, and their living conditions comfortable but not luxurious. explanation: Nanboku Tsuruya, also known as Tsuruya Namboku IV, was born in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, around 1755. His father was a merchant who sold used goods, which places their family in the middle class according to the social structure of Japan in the late 1700s. The middle class in this period was typically composed of merchants, artisans, and skilled craftspeople. While merchants were technically at the bottom of the social hierarchy in the Edo period, many were quite wealthy and had access to education and a comfortable lifestyle. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Tsuruya's family was particularly wealthy or that he had any inherited privileges. sources: "Kabuki's Forgotten Master: Tsuruya Namboku IV" by Satoko Shimazaki; "The Merchant's Tale: Yokohama and the Transformation of Japan" by Simon Partner.

explanation: Nishi Amane was born into a samurai family in Tsuwano, a castle town in the Iwami Province, which is now part of Shimane Prefecture, Japan. His father, Nishi Yoshisada, was a low-ranking samurai and a Confucian scholar. In the social structure of Japan during the late Edo period, samurai were considered part of the ruling class, but their economic status varied greatly. Many, like Nishi's family, were not wealthy and lived modestly. Despite their limited means, samurai families prioritized education, and Nishi was no exception. He received a traditional Confucian education from his father and later attended the domain school, Shōheikō, in Edo (now Tokyo). His family's status as samurai and his father's occupation as a scholar provided Nishi with access to education, a privilege not available to all during this period. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, reflecting the status of a low-ranking samurai family.
sources: "Nishi Amane and Modern Japanese Thought" by Thomas David Cuddy, "The Birth of Japan's Postwar Constitution" by Koseki Shoichi, and "The Samurai: A Military History" by Stephen Turnbull.

explanation: Shōkadō Shōjō, also known as Suzuki Shōsan, was born into a samurai family. His father was a retainer of the Oda clan, one of the most powerful samurai clans of the time. However, it's important to note that the wealth and status of samurai families could vary greatly, and some were closer to the subsistence class while others were closer to the elite class. In the case of Shōkadō Shōjō, specific details about his family's wealth and status are not well-documented, but given his samurai background, it's reasonable to classify him as middle class.

explanation: Utagawa Yoshitsuya, born in 1822, was the son of a Kioto dealer in dyestuffs. explanation: Kikuchi Yōsai, also known as Kikuchi Takeyasu, was born in Edo (modern-day Tokyo), Japan, in 1788. His father, Kikuchi Yōhei, was a samurai and a member of the middle class. explanation: Namiki Sōsuke was born into a family of dyers, an occupation that falls into the category of skilled craftspeople. explanation: Aoki Mokubei was born into a family of potters in Kyoto, Japan. explanation: Suzuki Shōnen was born in the late Edo period in Japan, a time when the social structure was rigidly hierarchical. explanation: Sakuma Shōzan was born into a samurai family in the Matsumoto domain. The samurai were a military class in Japan, often serving as bureaucrats, administrators, and warriors. Sakuma himself was able to study Confucianism from a young age, indicating that his family had the resources to provide him with an education.
